As a promising technology, the selective hydrogenation of CO2 to ethanol using CuFeZn catalysts has attracted significant attention. This study systematically investigates the mechanism of the hydrogenation of CO2 to ethanol over the CuFeZn model catalyst using periodic density functional theory (DFT), with particular focus on the key steps in CO2 hydrogenation. The calculations indicate that the formation of the CO* species is crucial for the production of CH3CH2OH, which requires overcoming an energy barrier of 1.91 eV. The coupling of CO* with CH3* is the rate-determining step, which involves overcoming an energy barrier of 2.77 eV. Further analysis shows that the CuFeZn catalyst’s synergistic effect significantly influences CO2 activation and the coupling reaction between CO* and CH3*, thereby enhancing CH3CH2OH formation. The high catalytic performance of the CuFeZn catalyst is attributed to the synergistic interactions between the active Fe5C2 and Cu. Density of States (DOS) and Electronic Localization Function (ELF) analyses show that the elevated Cu d-band center and the high electronic localization of FeⅣ in Fe5C2 enhance the formation of CO* species, thus promoting ethanol synthesis. In summary, by utilizing multiple active components to modulate the generation of CO* species and their activation barriers for coupling with CH3*, the selective production of ethanol can be significantly improved. This study underscores the crucial role of the CuFeZn catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to ethanol, providing valuable theoretical insights for future catalyst design and optimization. Graphical Abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Ethanol CuFeZn catalyst The synergistic effects Density functional theory Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Global climate change has drawn significant attention from governments and research institutions around the world. As a major greenhouse gas, Carbon dioxide (CO2) directly contributes to global warming, which causes environmental issues such as extreme weather and rising sea levels[1–7]. To mitigate the problem of greenhouse effect, various methods for capturing and utilizing CO2 have garnered considerable interest from researchers[8,9]. The CCUS technologies are considered vital in combating the greenhouse effect[10]. Among these, CO2 utilization technologies, which convert CO2 into valuable chemicals, not only reduce emissions but also address the demand for green energy[11]. Ethanol, an important chemical feedstock and fuel, is widely used in industrial and energy sectors due to its renewable nature and environmental friendliness[12,13]. Hydrogenation of CO2 to produce ethanol helps to reduce CO2 and meets the urgent requirements of green energy. However, the complex synthesis process presents challenges, particularly in catalyst development and reaction mechanisms [14]. Therefore, efficient ethanol synthesis depends heavily on the strategic design of catalysts. The choice of catalyst for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction directly affects both the activity and selectivity of the reaction [15–17]. Traditional catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to alcohols, such as Cu and In, exhibit excellent performance in the conversion of CO2 to methanol. Cu catalyst possesses good ability for CO2 activation as well as the non-dissociative activation of CO, making them candidates for this process[18–28]. However, the C-C coupling ability of Cu is poor. Therefore, the production of ethanol is poor for single Cu catalyst. By introducing alkali metals (K，Na), the ability of Cu-based catalysts to adsorb and dissociate CO into CHx* can be enhanced. Guo [10] found that the introduction of K can improve the formation of ethanol over CuZn catalysts, but the C-C coupling ability is still poor. Therefore, it is essential to integrate multiple functional active components to facilitate the production of ethanol. Fe-based catalysts demonstrate excellent ability to promote carbon chain growth. With the combination of Cu and Fe, the synthesis of ethanol can be facilitated by achieving the balance between CO dissociative adsorption and non-dissociative adsorption. Iron carbide (Fe5C2) are used as the catalysts to improve the ability of C-C coupling by adding co-catalysts to improve dispersion and electron transfer, as well as by tuning the surface electronic properties[29–32]. For example, Si et al.[33] designed a NaCuFe catalyst using a self-made method, achieving a total space-time yield of 833 mg gcat −1 h−1 for olefin and ethanol at 310 °C and 3 MPa. The highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles combined with Fe5C2 simplified both CO2 activation and C-C coupling process. Yang et al. [34] synthesized a nitrogen-doped CuFe (Fe5C2) Zn catalyst using the nitrogen-containing organic ligand PDA as a complexing agent, which enhances electron transfer and promotes the formation of low-valent Cu and Fe, thereby benefiting C2+ alcohol synthesis. Zhang et al. [35,36] modified the CuFe (Fe5C2) catalyst by incorporating a small amount of Cr, which inhibited the excessive dissociation of CO and promoted the production of acetate and acetaldehyde intermediates. The Cr (1 %)-CuFe catalyst achieved high C2+ alcohols selectivity of 29.2 % at 320 °C and 4 MPa. Although CuFe based catalyst have demonstrated high space-time yields for ethanol, the selectivity for ethanol remains low. Moreover, the reaction mechanism for CO2-to-ethanol conversion over CuFeZn catalysts is highly complicated. Therefore, designing catalysts with high ethanol selectivity requires systematic theoretical calculations to gain a deeper understanding of the reaction mechanism and the structure-activity relationship This study aims to explore the reaction mechanism of CO₂ hydrogenation to ethanol (CH₃CH₂OH) over Cu/Fe₅C₂/ZnO catalysts through theoretical computations. Through density of states (DOS) and electron localization function (ELF) analysis, it’s found that the d-band center of Cu in the CuFeZn catalyst is elevated, which plays a crucial role in enhancing the activation of CO₂. Additionally, the FeIV in Fe₅C₂ exhibits high electron localization, which contributes to the effective interaction with CO species during the hydrogenation process. Furthermore, our study demonstrates that the synergy between Fe₅C₂ and Cu not only promotes CO₂ activation but also facilitates the coupling of CO* and CH₃* intermediates. This synergistic interaction enhances the formation of ethanol by improving both the CO₂ activation and the C-C coupling steps. By using a combination of DFT calculations and in-situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy, we systematically investigate the reaction pathways for CO₂ hydrogenation to ethanol over CuFeZn catalysts. Our findings highlight the critical role of CO species formation and identify the rate-determining step as the coupling of CO and CH₃* intermediates, which significantly impacts the ethanol selectivity. 2 Model and computational details 2.1 Source of catalyst selection The CuFeZn catalyst was also prepared by a novel solvothermal method. In order to further investigate the active phases of the catalyst, the CuFeZn catalyst was characterized by XRD and TEM, and the results are shown in Fig. 1. From Fig. 1 (a-c), it can be seen that the spent CuFeZn catalyst retains the microsphere structure with uniform size. Fig. 1 (d) shows the XRD patterns of the spent CuFeZn catalysts, and the characteristic Cu peaks appeared at 2θ of 44.16°, 50.15°, and 73.21° which correspond to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0), and (2 2 0) crystallographic surfaces of Cu (JCPDS 03–1015). The Fe5C2 peaks appeared at 2θ of 30°, 35° and 43.15°, which correspond to the (0 0 4), (1 1 2) and (5 1 0) crystallographic surface of Fe5C2 ( JCPDS 36–1248), indicating respectively the presence of Fe5C2 after reaction. In conclusion, the CuFeZn catalyst active sites were proved by the above characterization, which provided a reference for the subsequent theoretical calculation modeling. Meanwhile, the lattice fringes of the Cu(1 1 1) crystal plane and the Fe5C2 (5 1,0) crystal plane can be clearly seen from Fig. 1 (e-f). 2.2 Foundation for model construction To reveal the synergistic effects of the Cu, Fe, and Zn components, we modeled the Cu/Fe5C2/ZnO ternary catalyst for the first time, depositing stable Fe5C2 clusters[35,37] and hydrogenated ZnO clusters (Zn6O7H7) [38,39] onto a bilayer Cu(1 1 1) surface. In the Cu/Fe5C2/ZnO model, the bottom layer is fixed in its optimized bulk position, while the top layer containing the Fe and Zn components, is allowed to relax during geometric optimization. Additionally, a 15 Å vacuum gap perpendicular to the surface is included to prevent interactions between any two adjacent layers. As shown in Fig. 2, the adsorption sites on the surface of the Cu/Fe5C2/ZnO catalyst involved in CO2 hydrogenation are tagged as, Cuhcp, FeII, FeIV and Cutop. 2.3 Computational parameters and related formulas This work uses the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP)[40,41] for density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The exchange-correlation energy was computed using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA). The projector augmented wave (PAW) method [42] was employed to model electron-ion interactions, with a plane-wave energy cutoff set to 400 eV. Dispersion-corrected DFT (DFT-d) was used to describe van der Waals (vdW) interactions[43]. Additionally, the maximum force on each relaxed atom was converged to less than 0.01 eV/Å, and the Brillouin zone was sampled with a 3 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack grid for all calculations. Isolated atoms and molecules were modeled using a 9 × 9 × 3 cubic unit cell. Utilizing the Climbing Image Nudged Elastic Band (CI-NEB) and DIMER methods to search for transition states (TSs) [44]. The former method is used when both the initial and final states are known, while the latter method is employed to search for transition states using a preliminary structure. Frequency analysis has been employed to verify the optimized transition state structure using a single imaginary frequency. Under the same conditions, density of states (DOS) analysis, COHP analysis, electronic localization function (ELF) analysis, and Bader charge analysis [45] were conducted to investigate the electronic transfer properties associated with adsorbate-surface interactions. The adsorption energies ( ∆ E ads ) of all species were obtained using the following equation in Eq. (1.1): (1.1) ∆ E ads = E adsorbate / slab − ( E ads + E slab ) where E ads ， E slab ， and E adsorbate / slab represent the total energies of the free adsorbate， the clean Cu/Fe5C2/ZnO slab, and the slab with the adsorbate, respectively. The reaction energy ( ∆ E ) and activation barrier ( E a ) were calculated in Eq. (1.2) ， Eq. (1.3): (1.2) ∆ E = E FS − E IS (1.3) E a = E TS − E IS where E IS ， E TS ， and E FS correspond to the total energies of the initial state (IS)， transition state (TS), and final state (FS), respectively. Considering the effects of zero-point vibrational energy (ZPE), thermal energy, and entropy on the standard molar Gibbs free energy, thermodynamic statistical formulas based on partition functions are employed to correct the energies obtained directly from DFT calculations. The standard molar Gibbs free energy can be derived in Eq. (1.4). (1.4) G θ ( T , p ) = E total + E ZPE + U θ − T S θ + γ RT [ 1 + ln ( p / p θ ) ] Herein, E total represents the total energy from DFT calculations, E ZPE is the zero-point vibrational energy, and U θ and S θ are the thermal energy and entropy, respectively. γ is 0 for surface adsorbates and 1 for gaseous molecules. R is the gas constant, and p is the partial pressure of the gas-phase molecules. As shown in Table S5, a temperature of 628.15 K was selected for the equations of the activation barrier ( ∆ G a ) and reaction energy ( ∆ G ). Based on the values of ∆ E and E a , exploring the optimal reaction pathway for syngas conversion over the CuFeZn catalyst is feasible. To account for the effect of temperature on syngas conversion over the CuFeZn catalyst, the rate constants at different reaction temperatures were calculated using transition state theory (TST) [46–48]. The corresponding equations[49,50] can be described in Eq. (1.5). (1.5) k = A exp − E a RT = k B T h Q TS Q R exp − E a RT Here, A ， E a ， T ， k B , and h denote the pre-exponential factor, activation energy, reaction temperature, Boltzmann constant, and Planck constant, respectively. Q TS and Q R represent the partition functions per unit volume for the transition state and the reactants, respectively. According to statistical thermodynamics, the partition function per unit volume ( Q ) can be approximated using the vibrational partition function in Eq. (1.6). (1.6) Q vib = ∏ i exp ( − h v i / 2 k B T ) 1 − exp ( − h v i / k B T ) Here, v i is the frequency of the vibrational mode i .Therefore, the pre-exponential factor [51] can be calculated in Eq. (1.7). (1.7) A = k B T h Q TS vib Q R vib 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Adsorption and activation of CO2 and dissociation of H2 For CuFeZn catalysts, Fe are often deemed as active sites for both CO2 activation and C-C coupling in CO2 hydrogenation reactions[33,36]. At the same time, Cu, a traditional RWGS catalyst, typically acts as the site where hydrogenation reactions occur. Therefore, the dissociation and adsorption of H2 primarily could occur on the CuZn surface [52]. This leads us to investigate how CO2 and H2 are activated and how the reactions proceed on different catalyst surfaces. We calculated the structural parameters and adsorption energies of CO2 before and after adsorption, as well as Bader charges and charge density differences following CO2 adsorption. The adsorption parameters are summarized in Table 1, and the stable CO2 configurations on different surfaces are shown in Fig. S1. Our results indicate that Fe5C2 is the activation site for CO2 adsorption, while ZnO plays a key role in H2 dissociation. When CO2 is adsorbed onto the Cu (1 1 1) surface, the interaction is too weak, resulting in free CO2 molecules after relaxation. The adsorption energies are negative, indicating that this type of adsorption is characteristic of physical adsorption. On the Fe5C2 (5 1 0) surface, the C–O bond lengths increase to 1.297 Å and 1.220 Å (compared to 1.177 Å in the free molecule), and the bond angle adjusts to 131.7°. For CO2 adsorption on the CuFe and CuFeZn surfaces, the adsorption energies range from −0.226 to −0.662 eV. Specifically, on the CuFeZn surface, the C–O bond lengths are extended to 1.282 Å and 1.220 Å (compared to 1.177 Å in the free molecule), and the bond angle shifts to 137.9°. As illustrated in Fig. 3, CO2 is exclusively adsorbed on the Fe atoms of Fe5C2, with the Bader charge contribution from Fe sites ranging from −0.50 to −0.53 |e|. The Bader charge distribution of the C atom in CO2 ranges from −1.44 to −2.11 |e|, while the Bader charge on Oa varies from 0.00 to −1.11 |e|, and on Ob ranges from 1.01 to 1.11 |e|. The net charges of CO2 adsorbed on the Fe5C2 (5 1 0) surface, CuFe surface, and CuFeZn surface are 0.66 |e|, 0.01 |e|, and −0.33 |e|, respectively. This suggests that the synergistic effect of the multiple metals gradually increases the electron donation to CO2, which helps to attract the positively charged H* to interact with CO2. Additionally, it facilitates the dissociation of the negatively charged CO2 into CO* and O* species, allowing the subsequent reaction to proceed. The fractional wave state density of CO2 on FeⅣ before and after adsorption activation on the CuFe surface and the fractional wave state density on CO2 after adsorption are shown in Fig. S14. There is a significant overlap between the orbitals of CO2 and FeⅣ near the Fermi energy level, and in particular, the β spin orbitals are better matched in terms of their energies, which suggests that a chemical bond was formed between CO2 and FeⅣ atoms. In order to further analyze the crystal orbital Hamiltonian preoccupation (COHP) of FeⅣ-O bond and C-O bond after adsorption activation, and the results are plotted in Fig. S15. For the FeⅣ-O bond, the presence of many antibonding orbitals in the antibonding state below the Fermi energy level indicates that the FeⅣ-O bond is not stable after adsorption activation. For the C-O bond on CO2, the bonding state below the Fermi energy level is significantly higher than the antibonding state, indicating that the C-O bonding is more stable, which is unfavorable for the dissociation activation of CO2. Therefore, whether evaluating the CO2 adsorption ability alone or its role in promoting the subsequent reactions, the CuFeZn catalytic surface exhibits the best performance among the three surfaces. Additionally, the stable adsorption configurations of CO2 on the CuFeZn surface are shown in Fig. 4 (a). Possible activation pathways include CO-mediated pathway, formate intermediate pathway, and the COOH* intermediate pathway The stable configurations after activation are illustrated in Fig. 4 (b), (c), (d). For CO2 dissociation on FeVI, forming CO*+O*, CO adsorbs on the interface with a C-O bond length of 1.20 Å, and O adsorbs at the Cuhcp position with an average Cu-O distance of 1.94 Å. Moreover, the reaction energy (ΔE) for this process is 1.84 eV, indicating that CO2 dissociation is an endothermic process. For the formate (HCOO*) and carboxyl (COOH*) intermediates, the reaction energies are −4.00 eV and −3.28 eV, respectively, indicating that these processes are exothermic. It is clear that, regardless of the CO2 activation mode, the presence of Cu or Zn with specific crystal facets enhances the initial activation of CO2, which could facilitate the subsequent reaction. Dissociative adsorption of H2 plays a key role in CO2 hydrogenation. As shown in Fig. 4 (e), Fig. S2 , The H2 molecule first physically adsorbs on top of ZnO and then dissociates into two H*, one migrating to the Cu and Fe5C2 interface to provide hydrogen atoms for the subsequent hydrogenation process. The dissociation energy for H2 is 0.71 eV, with an average Fe-H bond length of 1.69 Å. After dissociation, the H* adsorbs on the Cu surface and reacts with the carbon atom in the intermediate adsorbed on FeVI, facilitating the hydrogenation reaction. In addition, the introduction of ZnO could affect the stability of the CO* intermediate and promote the desorption of methanol. As shown in Table S6, the adsorption energy of CO* intermediates on the CuFe surface were −1.68 eV, while the adsorption energy of CO* intermediates on the CuFeZn surface was −0.44 eV. The proper adsorption energy on the CuFeZn surface not only enhanced the desorption of CO* intermediates, but also facilitated the following C-C coupling reactions for ethanol synthesis. Meanwhile，As shown in Table S7, methanol desorption requires 1.15 eV on the CuFe surface, whereas the energy decreases to 0.80 eV on the CuFeZn surface. This reduction highlights that the introduction of ZnO significantly facilitates methanol desorption, thereby enhancing the progression of CO₂ hydrogenation toward methanol synthesis. 3.2 Reaction pathways for CO2 hydrogenation As illustrated in literature, apart from CH3CH2OH, C1 products such as CO, CH4, and CH3OH are often formed during the hydrogenation of CO2 [53]. Thus, the possible reaction pathways of the above four product are all investigated. We first examine the reaction pathways for CO2 hydrogenation on the Cu/Fe5C2/ZnO surface. The hydrogenation of CO2 may follow three reaction pathways: (1) the CO-mediated pathway, (2) the HCOO* intermediate pathway, and (3) the COOH* intermediate pathway. According to previous studies [15,17], the CO-mediated route apply in various Cu- and Fe-based model catalysts are studied to explore the CO2 hydrogenation mechanism on Cu/Fe5C2/ZnO. DFT calculations are performed on Fe5C2/Zn6O7H7/Cu(1 1 1) (Fig. 2) to model the Cu-Fe5C2-ZnO interface. Fig. 4 displays the stable configurations of adsorption intermediates in the hydrogenation process. Key parameters, including activation energies (Ea) and reaction energies (ΔE), are determined for critical steps. Frequency analysis confirm the optimized transition state structures. This section focuses on the production of CO, CH4, CH3OH, and CH3CH2OH. 3.2.1 Formation of CO and CH4 During ethanol synthesis, CO and CH₄ are also produced. Fig. 5 shows the structures of the initial, transition, and final states for CO₂ hydrogenation to CO, and Fig. 6 illustrates the same for the hydrogenation to CH₄. CO₂ adsorbs onto Fe atom with an adsorption energy of 0.26 eV. Its dissociation occurs via Fe and Cu interactions, resulting in CO* and O* on Fe and the Cu(1 1 1) surface, with a reaction energy of −0.08 eV(Ea = 1.91 eV). CO* desorbs with a reaction energy of 0.44 eV, while further dissociation to C* releases −0.13 eV(Table S5). This shows that CO* dissociation and desorption are facile, highlighting the importance of balancing CO₂ dissociation and CO* desorption for efficient C-C coupling in ethanol formation. As shown in Fig. 6 and Table S5, the dissociation of CO* forms C* species that react with H* on the Cu(1 1 1) surface, producing CH*, CH₂*, and CH₃* species, with reaction energies of −0.31 eV, −0.84 eV, and −0.77 eV, respectively. The stepwise hydrogenation requires overcoming reaction barriers of 0.35 eV, 0.18 eV, and 0.06 eV, respectively. This shows that the hydrogenation of C* is exothermic. The conversion of CH₂* to CH₃* is the critical step in CO₂ hydrogenation to ethanol [36,54], while CH₃* can also form CH₄*, which desorbs as CH₄ with a reaction energy of −3.49 eV. It can be observed that the consecutive hydrogenation is easier compared to CO2 dissociation, indicating that CO* formation is the key step in the synthesis of ethanol.。 3.2.2 Formation of CH3OH As shown in Fig. S3, two reaction pathways are proposed for the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol, referred to as RWGS + CO Hydro pathway and the formate pathway [55–57]. The former initiates with the reverse water-gas shift reaction (RWGS: CO2+ H2→ CO + H2O), generating the CO intermediate via carboxyl species (COOH*), which is subsequently hydrogenated to CH3OH. The latter proceeds through formate (HCOO*) intermediates, where C-O bond cleavage and HCO*/H2CO*formation lead to methanol synthesis [56]. To elucidate the mechanism on Cu-Fe-Zn catalysts, including the key intermediates and rate-limiting steps, the potential energy diagram for the hydrogenation of CO2 to CH3OH on Cu/Fe5C2/ZnO was calculated, as shown in Fig. 7. Adsorption and activation of CO2 on Fe5C2 involve co-adsorption of C and O atoms on Fev sites (ΔE = -1.05 eV), contrasting with the linear CO2 configuration on pure Cu(1 1 1). This highlights the role of Fe5C2/ZnO in stabilizing carboxylate species (CO2*), enhancing catalytic activity. As depicted in Fig. 7, the RWGS + CO Hydro pathway initiates with CO2* hydrogenation to form COOH* (ΔE = -3.28 eV), followed by dissociation into CO* and OH* (ΔE = 1.51 eV). CO generated via RWGS may either desorb with a high energy barrier or be further hydrogenated to CHO* (ΔE = -4.01 eV). Entropic effects under elevated temperature (220°C) and pressure reduce the desorption barrier by ∼1 eV, making CO the predominant product. Therefore, On Cu/Fe5C2/ZnO, limited CO* participates in subsequent steps, forming CHO*, CH2O* (ΔE = -4.54 eV), CH2OH* (ΔE = -2.91 eV), and ultimately CH3OH* (ΔE = -4.26 eV), which desorbs as methanol (ΔE = 0.80 eV). As shown in Fig. 7, the Formate pathway begins with the exothermic hydrogenation of CO2* to HCOO* (ΔE = -4.00 eV). Subsequent steps involve HCOO* conversion to HCOOH* (ΔE = -2.79 eV) and H2COOH* (ΔE = -4.74 eV). C-O bond cleavage of H2COOH* generates H2CO* (ΔE = 1.14 eV), followed by hydrogenation to CH2OH* and CH3OH*, which desorb as methanol. DFT results indicate that Cu and Fe enhance CO2 adsorption and conversion on Fe sites by balancing dissociative and non-dissociative adsorption. In the RWGS+CO Hydro pathway, unstable intermediates (e.g., CO*, HCO*) limit full methanol synthesis, favoring CO production. Conversely, the formate pathway’s stable HCOO* species may cause surface toxicity. Experimental data [36,54] confirm the low methanol selectivity on CuFeZn, aligning with these findings. Therefore, along the RWGS+CO Hydro pathway not only prevents catalyst surface poisoning but also improves the key intermediates, both of which are favorable for CO2 hydrogenation on CuFeZn for methanol synthesis. 3.2.3 Formation of CH3CH2OH As illustrated in Fig.S4, there are three primary pathways for the CO2-to-ethanol hydrogenation [55–57], the methanol-mediated (blue arrow), the CO-mediated (green arrow) and the formate-mediated (black arrow). The difference between these pathways lies in the intermediates generated after CO2 adsorption and activation. CO-mediated pathway: CO2 undergoes RWGS to form CO, which is hydrogenated to CH3*. CO inserts into CH3*, yielding CH3CO*, followed by hydrogenation to ethanol. Formate-mediated pathway: CO2 hydrogenation forms HCOO*, which converts to H2COOH*. C-O cleavage and hydrogenation generate CH3*, which couples with CO* and undergoes hydrogenation to ethanol. Methanol-mediated pathway: CO (from COOH* cleavage) is hydrogenated to methanol, releasing OH* to form CH3*. Subsequent coupling with CO* and hydrogenation completes ethanol synthesis. To explore the reaction pathways and rate-limiting steps of CO₂ hydrogenation to ethanol on Cu/Fe₂C₅/ZnO, a potential energy diagram was constructed for the catalytic conversion of CO₂ (g) to CH₃CH₂OH (g). Fig. 8 illustrates three key pathways: the CO-mediated, formate-mediated, and methanol-mediated routes. As previously described, ethanol formation begins with the adsorption and activation of CO2 on Fe5C2 to form CO*. In the CO-mediated pathway shown by the black line in Fig. 8, CO2* directly dissociates to form CO* (ΔE = 8.30 eV) and C* (ΔE = 6.96 eV), which are endothermic. To stabilize the system, the C* species is bonded to Fe atom. The following three-step hydrogenation produces CH* (ΔE = -3.75 eV), CH2* (ΔE = -4.30 eV), and CH3* (ΔE = -4.23 eV), which are exothermic. Then, CH3* and CO* undergo C-C coupling to form CH3CO* (ΔE = -1.71 eV)[15–17]. CH3CO* undergoes further hydrogenation to form CH3COH* (ΔE = -3.59 eV), CH3CHOH* (ΔE = -3.44 eV), and CH3CH2OH* (ΔE = -4.44 eV) intermediates, and finally, CH3CH2OH* desorbs to form the ethanol molecule (ΔE = 0.50 eV). The formate-mediated pathway (green line in Fig. 8) initiates with hydrogenation of CO2* to HCOO* (ΔE = -4.11 eV). Subsequent steps generate HCOOH* (ΔE = -2.67 eV) and H2COOH* (ΔE = -4.74 eV) via consecutive hydrogenation. Cleavage of the C-O bond in H2COOH* produces H2CO* (ΔE = 1.14 eV). Further hydrogenation of H2CO* yields H2COH* (ΔE = -2.87 eV), followed by C-O bond cleavage to CH2* (ΔE = 1.46 eV). Hydrogenation of CH2* forms CH3* (ΔE = -4.23 eV), which couples with CO* to generate CH3CO* (ΔE = -1.71 eV). A hydrogenation sequence analogous to the CO-mediated pathway then leads to intermediates: CH3COH* (ΔE = -3.59 eV), CH3CHOH* (ΔE = -3.44 eV), and CH3CH2OH* (ΔE = -4.44 eV). Ethanol is finally released through desorption of CH3CH2OH* (ΔE = 0.50 eV). As for the methanol-mediated pathway, as depicted by the blue line in Fig. 8 CO2* is hydrogenated to form COOH* (ΔE = -3.28 eV). The C-O bond in COOH* then breaks to form CO* (ΔE = 1.51 eV). which subsequently undergoes four consecutive hydrogenation steps to form the following intermediates, including CHO* (ΔE = -4.01 eV), CH2O* (ΔE = -4.54 eV), CH2OH* (ΔE = -2.95 eV), and CH3OH* (ΔE = -4.30 eV). The C-O bond in CH3OH* then breaks to form CH3* (ΔE = -1.47 eV), which undergo C-C coupling with CO* to form CH3CO* (ΔE = -1.71 eV). The subsequent hydrogenation steps are similar to the CO-mediated pathway with the following intermediates, CH3COH* (ΔE = -3.59 eV), CH3CHOH* (ΔE = -3.44 eV), and CH3CH2OH* (ΔE = -4.44 eV). Finally, CH3CH2OH* desorbs to form ethanol (ΔE = 0.50 eV). In summary, formate-mediated and methanol-mediated pathways are unfavorable in the hydrogenation of CO₂ to ethanol, which are due to the high energy barriers in their key steps and the instability of intermediates. Taking the formate pathway as example, although HCOO* generated from the hydrogenation of CO₂ shows exothermic properties (ΔE = -4.11 eV) in the initial stage, the subsequent cleavage of the C-O bond of H₂COOH* requires overcoming significant energy barrier of 1.14 eV, and the generated H₂CO* still needs to overcome energy barrier of 1.46 eV when further hydrogenated to CH₂*, which are kinetically unfavorable. The ΔE of key intermediates in the formate-mediated and methanol-mediated pathways are high, which make them unstable in the reaction. Moreover, the formate-mediated and methanol-mediated pathways are more complicated than the CO-mediated pathway. Thus the formate-mediated and methanol-mediated pathways are considered less favorable. 3.2.4 Optimal pathways for the synthesis of CO，CH4，CH3OH and CH3CH2OH Overall，the optimal pathways for the synthesis of CO, CH4, CH3OH, and CH3CH2OH are as follows. For CO and CH4, the pathway is CO2 → CO + O (Fig. S5) → CO → CO(g) → C + O (Fig. S6)→ C → C + H → CH (Fig. S7)→ CH + H → CH2 (Fig. S8)→ CH2 + H → CH3 (Fig. S9)→ CH4. For CH3CH2OH, the pathway is CH3 + CO → CH3CO (Fig. S10)→ CH3CO + H → CH3COH (Fig. S11)→ CH3COH + H → CH3CHOH (Fig. S12)→ CH3CHOH + H → CH3CH2OH(Fig. S13). For CH3OH, the pathway is CO2 → COOH → CO → CHO → CH2O → CH2OH → CH3OH，the optimal reaction pathways is shown in Fig. 9. The catalytic cycles for ethanol synthesis on Cu/Fe5C2/ZnO illustrate that ethanol formation involves CO2 activation, formation of CH3*, and C-C coupling. Black arrows represent the reaction pathway of ethanol synthesis (ES). Based on the ΔG results, the rate-limiting step in ethanol synthesis is the C-C coupling, corresponding to ΔGa of 2.96 eV (628.15 K). The generation of key intermediates during CO₂ hydrogenation for ethanol synthesis over CuFeZn catalysts at 608.15 K was studied by time-dependent in situ DRIFTS, with results shown in Fig. 10. The peaks at 1575–1622 cm−1 and 2766–2845 cm−1 correspond to HCOO* species with C-H and COO vibrations, while those at 1415–1487 cm−1 correspond to CHₓ* species[36]. The peaks at 1575–1622 cm−1 correspond to CO* species. Therefore, it is proved that the optimal pathway for the hydrogenation of CuFeZn CO2 to synthesize ethanol is the CO-mediated reaction pathway. Notably, the intensity of HCOO* is much lower than CHₓ*. The peaks of CH3CO* species at 1733–1748 cm−1 and CH3CH2O* species at 2876–2966 cm−1 and 1285–1325 cm−1 suggest that aldehyde species are key intermediates in ES[54]. The successive appearance of intermediates such as CO*, CHx*, CH3CO*, CH3CH2O* etc., involves the RWGS, CO dissociation to CHₓ*, CO insertion, and alcohol generation in a series of processes, are consistent with the optimal reaction mechanism for ES. Additionally, the data indicate that the catalytic activity of the Cu/Fe5C2/ZnO catalyst stems from the synergistic effects of Cu/Fe5C2/ZnO, which facilitate both the insertion of CO into CH3 and the RWGS reaction to enhance the formation of CO*. Specifically, CO2 initially undergoes the RWGS reaction at Cu-ZnO and Fe5C2 sites to form CO*. Some of the CO* desorbs as CO (g), while some is hydrogenated to form CH3OH. The remaining CO* is activated and hydrogenated on FeⅤ sites to form CHx* species. These CHx* species then couple with CO* on Cu-FeⅤ sites through insertion and hydrogenation to produce CH3CHO* and final CH3CH2OH. Furthermore, Cu-ZnO sites can catalyze CO2 to directly produce CH3OH with HCOO* as intermediate. The formation of the C-C bond in CH3CH2OH through the insertion of CO* into CH3* requires the synergistic effect of Cu and Fe5C2, while the synergy effect between Cu-ZnO is also crucial for methanol formation. 3.3 Electronic structure analysis 3.3.1 Charge analysis Fig. 11 demonstrates the use of Bader charge and charge difference density analysis to understand CO* insertion into CHₓ* in ethanol synthesis and CO* formation in methanol synthesis. Bader charges on the clean Cu/ Fe5C2/ZnO surfaces were calculated. As shown in Fig. 11 (a) and Table S2, the charges on three Cu sites interacting with adjacent Fe5C2 species are −0.03 |e|, −0.17 |e|, and + 0.09 |e|, respectively. Charges on Cu sites around ZnO range from −0.01 |e| to + 0.03 |e|, and the charge on Zn is 0.97 |e|, while that on Fe ranges from −0.50 |e| to −0.37 |e|. The C sites in Fe5C2 have + 0.91 |e|, and O sites in ZnO have + 1.22 |e| (Table S2). This shows stronger electron transfer between the Cu (1 1 1) surface and Fe5C2. When CH₃* is adsorbed on the FeⅣ and FeII sites, as shown in Fig. 11 (b), forming CH₃* requires the synergistic effect of Cu- Fe5C2. Cu64 donates 0.06 |e| of charge, and the Bader charge of Cu64, with CH₃* adsorbed on the FeⅣ site, drops to 0.03 |e|. Since CO* donates more electrons, the charge on the FeII site decreases from −0.34 |e| to −0.45 |e|. For two Cu atoms near CH₃*, the electron-accepting effect causes their charges to change from 0.09 |e| and 0.03 |e| to 0.03 |e| and −0.01 |e|. Consequently, the net charges of CH₃* and CO* species are + 0.24 |e| and −0.43 |e| (Table S3), respectively. Clearly, CO* insertion into adjacent CH₃* for carbon chain growth is favorable, representing a nucleophilic attack mechanism. In Fig. 11 (b), charge density changes due to CH₃* and CO* adsorption on CuFeZn catalyst show increased charge density of CH₃* and CO* in yellow regions on equipotential surfaces, while decreased charge density in blue regions indicates co-adsorbed species. These results strongly support the nucleophilic attack mechanism of CO* on adjacent CH₃*. The CO* intermediate formation is the rate-determining step in methanol synthesis. Following CO2 dissociation into CO* and O*, the FeIV site in Fe5C2 exhibits a charge reduction from −0.37 |e| to −0.50 |e|. Electron transfer from CHO* species to the catalyst further lowers the FeIV charge (-0.34 |e| → −0.40 |e|) and reduces Cu site charges (-0.18 |e| to −0.02 |e|), resulting in a net CO* charge of + 0.41 |e| (Table S4). Fig. 11 (c) reveals that CO* adsorption induces charge density redistribution: yellow regions (electron accumulation) on CO* and blue regions (depletion) near FeIV, aligning with Bader charge data. This charge depletion at FeIV and accumulation on CO* enables CO* to bind H* for subsequent hydrogenation. 3.3.2 DOS and COHP analysis Fig. 12 shows the total density of states (TDOS) of the CuFeZn catalyst model (Fermi level marked by a black dashed line), indicating gapless conductivity. The partial density of states (PDOS) of its surface atoms further reveals their contributions: Cu and Zn dominate below the Fermi level, whereas Cu and Fe contribute predominantly above it (Fig. 12 a). The d-band center is a key descriptor for adsorption energy changes, as it influences the position and filling of the anti-bonding 2p states of CO₂ and Cu's d states. Moving left on the periodic table increases the energy of Cu's d states relative to the Fermi level, raising the energy of anti-bonding states, which results in less filling and stronger bonding. For example, the d-band center of pure Cu (1 1 1) is −2.67 eV [58], with a CO₂ adsorption energy of −0.03 eV. On the CuFeZn surface, the d-band center shifts to −2.49 eV, and CO₂ adsorption energy increases to −0.26 eV. This increase in CO₂ adsorption is linked to the rise in the d-band center, which is attributed to electronic structure changes from the interaction between ZnO, Fe5C2, and Cu (1 1 1), leading to stronger adsorption and enhanced reactivity of CuFeZn compared to pure Cu. To further understand the interaction between CO₂* and FeⅣ atoms, we analyzed the partial density of states (PDOS) for both before and after adsorption, as shown in Fig. 13 As seen in Fig. 13 (a), (b), the PDOS of CO₂ increases significantly after adsorption, while that of FeⅣ atoms decreases, indicating electron transfer from FeⅣ to CO₂*. This is confirmed by the appearance of isolated peaks below the Fermi level in the PDOS of CO2 after adsorption. The anti-σ bond of CO₂ interacts with the occupied d orbitals of FeⅣ atoms. Following energy level splitting, some anti-bonding components rise above the Fermi level, allowing electrons to flow into CO₂ and increasing the energy of its bonding orbitals. The partial overlap of CO₂ and FeⅣ atomic orbitals near the Fermi level indicates the formation of a chemical bond, reflecting strong chemical adsorption. In the CuFeZn model with CO₂ adsorption, CO₂ activation on the Fe5C2 surface results in Fe-O and Fe-C bond formation. The anti-σ bond of CO₂ interacts with the d orbitals of FeⅣ atoms. After energy splitting, some anti-bonding components move above the Fermi level, causing electron flow into CO₂ and increasing the energy of its bonding orbitals. The overlap of CO₂ and FeⅣ atomic orbitals near the Fermi level indicates the formation of a chemical bond and strong adsorption. In the optimized CuFeZn model, CO₂ activation on the Fe5C2 surface results in Fe-O and Fe-C bonds. To examine the bonding interactions between CO₂* and FeⅣ atoms, we analyzed the crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) for the FeⅣ-O, FeⅣ-C, and C-O bonds of CO₂, based on the projected density of states (Fig. 13 (c)). For the FeⅣ-O bond, many anti-bonding orbitals lie below the Fermi level, indicating instability after adsorption. In the FeⅣ-C bond, the anti-bonding orbitals near the Fermi level overlap with those of the C-O bond. However, only the FeⅣ-C bonding orbitals show peaks near the Fermi level, making this bond more stable than the C-O bond in CO₂. For the C-O bond in CO₂, anti-bonding states are higher than bonding states below the Fermi level, suggesting reduced stability. The ICOHP values were calculated, with FeⅣ-C, C-Oa, and C-Ob bonds at −0.27 eV (downspin −0.25 eV), −0.51 eV (downspin −0.30 eV), and −0.43 eV (downspin −0.30 eV), respectively. The C-Oa bond in the adsorbed CO₂ is more stable than the C-Ob bond, facilitating CO₂ dissociation and activation. 3.3.3 ELF Analysis To better understand the origin of the enhanced interactions between CO2 and different catalyst surfaces, we analyzed the electronic structure by calculating the electronic localization function (ELF) for various surfaces. As shown in Fig. 14 (a), the ELF on the Cu (1 1 1) surface is below 0.5, indicating that the surface electrons are mainly associated with the Cu atomic cores, resulting in a low degree of electron localization. In contrast, on the Fe5C2(5 1 0) surface, the ELF for some Fe atoms exceeds 0.5, with the FeⅣ atoms in the Fe5C2 cluster approaching 0.7. This suggests that electron pairs can exist independently of atomic cores, creating regions of high electron localization, which enhances electronic transfer and chemical adsorption with CO2. Consequently, loading single Fe5C2 clusters onto the Cu (1 1 1) surface facilitates the hydrogenation of CO2 to produce ethanol. 3.4 Rate constant analyses The rate constants for the optimal ethanol formation pathways on the CuFeZn surface, within the temperature range of 608.15 K to 648.15 K, are listed in Table 2. For CH₃CH₂OH synthesis, the rate-determining step is the formation of the intermediate CH₃CH₂OH*, with rate constants ranging from 1.05 × 10 ¹ ³ to 1.13 × 10 ¹ ³ s⁻¹ . The step with the maximum rate constant is the coupling process of the CH3* and CO* intermediates, with rate constants increasing with reaction temperature, ranging from 1.41 × 10⁻¹⁰ to 3.91 × 10⁻⁹ s⁻¹. The corresponding rate constants for the formation of CH3* range from 4.03 × 10¹² to 4.61 × 10¹² s⁻¹. The rate constants for the gradual dissociation process of CO2* range from 1.88 × 10⁻³ to 1.90 × 10⁻² s⁻¹ and from 4.12 × 10⁻² to 3.46 × 10⁻¹ s⁻¹, respectively. It is noticeable that temperature has a negligible impact on the rate constants of the continuous hydrogenation for C* and CH₃CO* species. Nevertheless, when the temperature is identical, the hydrogenation sequence aligns with the values of the rate constants, suggesting that the steric hindrance in subsequent hydrogenation influences the reaction rate. Whether it is the formation of the CO* intermediate or the coupling process between the CH3* and CO* intermediates, the rate constants increase with rising temperature, indicating that higher temperatures speed up the rate of ethanol production. Therefore, an appropriate temperature is crucial for the hydrogenation of CO2 to form ethanol. 4 Conclusion We performed periodic DFT calculations to study the CO₂ hydrogenation mechanism to ethanol over the CuFeZn catalyst, focusing on the roles and synergistic effects of Cu, Fe₅C₂, and ZnO. Our results show that CO* formation is essential for producing the four main products: CO, CH₄, CH₃OH, and CH₃CH₂OH. Based on the analysis of activation energy in key steps and In-situ DRIFT spectra results, the presence of intermediates such as CO*, CHx*, CH3CO* was demonstrated. After evaluating three pathways, the CO-mediated route was identified as the optimal pathway for CO₂ hydrogenation to CH₃CH₂OH. For CH₃CH₂OH, the rate-determining step is C-C coupling, with the highest barrier of 2.77 eV. Bader charge and charge density analysis shows that both CH₃OH formation through CO* hydrogenation and CH₃CH₂OH formation via CO* insertion into CH₃* are favorable on the CuFeZn catalyst. Our findings suggest that the enhanced catalytic activity of CuFeZn results from the synergistic properties of Cu, Fe5C2, and ZnO. Specifically, the Cu-Fe5C2 synergy promotes the initial activation of CO2, the coupling of CO* and CH3*, and the formation of CH3CH2OH. Moreover, the activation of H2 dissociation benefits from the Cu-ZnO synergy. The DOS and electronic localization function (ELF) results show that the increased d-band center of Cu and the high electron localization purity of FeⅣ in Fe5C2 contribute to the enhanced adsorption ability of the CuFeZn catalyst. Therefore, introducing co-catalysts to adjust the activation barriers for CO* formation and CO* and CH3* coupling can effectively control the production rate and selectivity of target products on the CuFeZn catalyst. Overall, this research highlights the essential function of the CuFeZn catalyst in the hydrogenation of CO2 to ethanol, offering significant theoretical understandings for the design and optimization of further catalysts. coredata.dc:description: As a promising technology, the selective hydrogenation of CO2 to ethanol using CuFeZn catalysts has attracted significant attention. This study systematically investigates the mechanism of the hydrogenation of CO2 to ethanol over the CuFeZn model catalyst using periodic density functional theory (DFT), with particular focus on the key steps in CO2 hydrogenation. The calculations indicate that the formation of the CO* species is crucial for the production of CH3CH2OH, which requires overcoming an energy barrier of 1.91 eV. The coupling of CO* with CH3* is the rate-determining step, which involves overcoming an energy barrier of 2.77 eV. Further analysis shows that the CuFeZn catalyst’s synergistic effect significantly influences CO2 activation and the coupling reaction between CO* and CH3*, thereby enhancing CH3CH2OH formation. The high catalytic performance of the CuFeZn catalyst is attributed to the synergistic interactions between the active Fe5C2 and Cu. Density of States (DOS) and Electronic Localization Function (ELF) analyses show that the elevated Cu d-band center and the high electronic localization of FeⅣ in Fe5C2 enhance the formation of CO* species, thus promoting ethanol synthesis. In summary, by utilizing multiple active components to modulate the generation of CO* species and their activation barriers for coupling with CH3*, the selective production of ethanol can be significantly improved. This study underscores the crucial role of the CuFeZn catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to ethanol, providing valuable theoretical insights for future catalyst design and optimization.
